content.question: The derivative of the function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals the fraction with numerator x cubed plus 2 x, plus 6, and denominator x to the fourth power, minus 3 x, plus 2, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. If <math alttext="f of 2 equals 0.76" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.76</mn></mrow></math>, what is the approximation for <math alttext="f of 2.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> found by using the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization
